newsitem.title: USA: No Christmas shopping for U.S. astronaut.
newsitem.headline: No Christmas shopping for U.S. astronaut.

text.p: U.S. astronaut John Blaha will spend Christmas away from his family on Russia's Mir space station -- but at least he's avoided shopping for presents.
"This year I haven't had to worry about getting Christmas presents for anyone down on the planet," Blaha, 54, said in a satellite news conference on Thursday.
His wife Brenda helped by finding gifts for his two Russian crewmates, Valeri Korzun and Alexander Kaleri.
"A couple of days before launch, I asked her to run down and get me a couple of Christmas presents," he said.
As Blaha spoke from space with reporters in Florida and Texas, a spacesuit glove clutching a miniature Christmas tree floated in the Mir cabin.
Blaha, who is three months into a fourth-month stay on Mir, received a batch of gifts from his family last month, delivered to the station by an unmanned cargo craft.
On Christmas Day, the 54-year-old astronaut will talk with his family in a video linkup and will tuck into an international Christmas dinner.

"We are going to have an outstanding menu," Mir commander Valeri Korzun said. "A menu that will include both Russian and American products. We will have traditional cakes, lamb, pork and a wonderful desert as well as Italian food -- macaroni cheese."
